defect.para: This Recall applies to AmTran RE and FE, GENESIS, and AmTran Conventional buses built from October 1, 1998 through September 10, 1999.

American Transportation Corporation (AmTran) has determined that a defect relating to motor vehicle safety exists in some AmTran RE™, AmTran FE™, GENESIS™, and AmTran Conventional™ buses. This defect involves the seat mounting bolts for the rear leg of the two leg anchor (seat belt ready) seats mounted in buses without the plywood floor option.

Some of the buses involved in this recall were built with seat mounting bolts that failed during testing meeting the requirements of FMVSS 210. In the event of an accident, this defect could result in personal injury.
Owners are being notified of this recall and have been directed to contact an AmTran Alliance dealer to make arrangements for inspection and remedy of the defect.

svcproc.title: INSPECTION
svcproc.para: This photo ( Figure 1) shows the type of seat that is involved in this recall. Count the number of seats that match this photo. Please complete and return the "AUTHORIZATION FOR RECALL SERVICE" card checking one of the boxes, #3 through #6 or box #8. When checking box #8 enter the quantity of seats that match the photo. Make sure that your correct UPS shipping address (i.e., not a P.O. Box number) is on the card. This will enable AmTran to ship replacement bolts to your location.

svcproc.title: REPAIR PROCEDURE
svcproc.para: The repair procedure will involve replacing the existing two (2) bolts that secure the rear leg of the seat to the floor with bolts that have a shoulder between the head of the bolt and the threaded section.

laborinfo.para: Inspection and completion of documentation 0.2 hour.

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified from your dealer location.

The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner's vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair his vehicle as soon as possible.
